Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Wetlands in a Working Landscape: Links Among Landowner Decisions, Climate, Disease Ecology, and Metapopulation Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study ecological and social processes governing the structure and function of wetland ecosystems found in agricultural and rangelands in the Sierra Foothills of California where they have often been accidentally or purposefully created. These wetlands are important habitat for a threatened bird species, Black Rail, and can be a source of mosquitoes that carry the recently-arrived West Nile Virus, which affects both humans and wildlife. The goal of this research is to address the question of how landowner practices, attitudes, and perceptions of the costs, risks and benefits of maintaining wetlands have affected their number, size, and distribution, and in turn influenced mosquito populations, West Nile Virus prevalence, and the population dynamics of the Black Rail. The project will trace the appearance and disappearance of wetlands over the last 50 years from aerial photographs to develop measures of wetland change; survey wetland landowners to determine how they assess the costs and benefits of their wetlands; develop regional climate models that project the change in wetland size over the next 40 years with changing climate and irrigation practices; develop population models for rails that incorporate changes in wetland characteristics; quantify the relationships between the risk of being exposed to West Nile Virus and climate, land use, and wetland characteristics; and develop models that integrate these factors to forecast future changes in wetlands.

Over 90% of California's wetlands have been converted to other land uses. This project will quantify the processes that sustain the remaining inland wetlands on agricultural landscapes by uncovering interactions between wetlands, landowner decisions, and climate variation. Educational benefits include training of postdoctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students in research methods including opportunities for minority student participation, and developing course material for undergraduate and graduate students. Results from this research will be disseminated to a broader community through outreach to landowners, agencies, and stakeholders that manage wetlands in working landscapes. This work will also inform conservation efforts for a threatened species, the Black Rail, by determining impacts of disease and by providing models to evaluate regional development and landscape planning in a rapidly growing region of California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied ecological and social processes at hundreds of small wetlands found in agricultural and rangelands in the Sierra Foothills of California, where they have often been accidentally or purposefully created. These wetlands are also important habitat for the threatened Black Rail, and can be a source of mosquitoes that carry the recently-arrived West Nile Virus (WNV), which affects both humans and wildlife. We found declines in the regional Black Rail population that raise serious concerns for this state-protected species, where it is listed in California as a threatened species. There is only one other metapopulation of this species in the region in San Francisco Bay. We found that landowner decisions affected the number, size, and distribution of wetlands, intentionally or unintentionally increasing the acreage of habitat for rails over the past 50 years through the irrigation practices. Water and land uses by landowners influenced mosquito populations and WNV transmission. Mosquito abundance peaks slightly before West Nile virus prevalence, offsetting infection rates, but species-specific differences mean that infection risk remains a threat throughout the summer and the second half of the Black Rail breeding and fledging season. We conducted a survey of landowners that revealed many wetlands are ‘accidental’ and have little impact on land use or productivity from the land manager perspective. They are largely ignored by land managers, which may be why they have served as black rail habitat for decades under changing environmental and economic conditions. We found that landowners are interested in wildlife and over half would be willing to participate in programs designed to facilitate the creation of wetland habitats, but current institutional structures and management goals have led to wetlands being a “blind spot” in our irrigation policy and management decisions.

Over 90% of California’s wetlands have been converted to other land uses, and inland wetlands comprise half of what remains. We have identified key processes that sustain these inland wetlands on agricultural landscapes by uncovering interactions between wetlands, landowner decisions, and climate variation. We have learned how these factors affect a threatened wetland bird, the Black Rail, and the transmission of West Nile Virus in the face of climate warming. Educational benefits include training of 9 graduate students, 14 undergraduate students, 17 recently-graduated students, and 2 high school students in research methods including opportunities for minority student participation, and developing course material for undergraduate and graduate students. We extendrf our findings to a broader community by educating landowners, water management agencies, and other stakeholders that manage wetlands in working landscapes. Our work also advanced the conservation of a very secretive threatened species, the Black Rail, by determining impacts of disease and by providing models to evaluate regional development and conservation planning in a rapidly growing region of California.
